levels.level: This data satisfies the fundamental requirements for open data.
This data satisfies the requirements for initial forays into publishing open data. It provides sufficient support to prompt some reuser experimentation with a data.
This data satisfies the requirements for routinely published open data that encourages reuse.
This data satisfies the requirements for key information infrastructure.

What's the website for your organisation?

question.label: Where is your copyright statement?
question.help: The copyright and database right statement can indicate that you are waiving your rights over the data, or the licences under which you are publishing it.
question.requirement: You should have a page that states your copyright over the data and provides details of any attribution that people should use.

option.label: licences
option.requirement: Provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about the licences that should be used when the data is reused.

option.label: attribution
option.requirement: Provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about the attribution that should be used when the data is reused.

option.label: attribution URL
option.requirement: Provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about the URL that should be linked to when the data is reused.

option.label: additional permissions or alternative licences
non-binding use guidelines

question.help: If you have a copyright statement, it is good to embed within it machine-readable information about the licence under which you are making your data available under.

select.option: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)
Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: The creator of a database automatically gets database rights where they spend substantial effort gathering, verifying and presenting data. You need to have a waiver or licence that covers the database rights in the data so reusers know that they can reuse it.

What's the location the licence?

question.help: Indicate whether the licence is a recognised open licence under the Open Knowledge Definition.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under a licence that is open to enable others to reuse it.

question.label: Under which licence can others reuse the content?
question.help: The creator of content automatically gets copyright over that content when they spend intellectual effort creating it. Note that creative content does not include facts. You need to have a waiver or licence that covers the copyright in the data so reusers know that they can reuse it.

What's the location the licence?

question.help: Indicate whether the licence is a recognised open licence under the Open Knowledge Definition.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under a licence that is open to enable others to reuse it.

question.label: Are you UK central government?
question.help: Central government includes all government departments and arms-length bodies. It does not include local government. Data that is collected and maintained by central government is owned by the Crown, which means it must be published as open data under the Open Government Licence unless the publisher has an exemption from the Office of Public Sector Information.

question.label: Do you have a licensing exemption from OPSI?
question.help: Data that is collected and maintained by UK central government is owned by the Crown, which means it must be published as open data under the Open Government Licence unless the publisher has an exemption from the Office of Public Sector Information.

if.requirement: Unless you have been granted an exemption from OPSI, if you are UK central government then you must publish your content and data using the Open Government Licence.

question.label: Was all this data originally created or gathered by you?
question.help: If the data was not originally created or gathered by you then you might not have the right to republish it. Answer 'no' to this question if this data is based on data from outside your organisation or includes data that you have crowd-sourced.

question.label: Was some of this data extracted or calculated from other data?
question.help: Indicate whether you have created this data based on data from elsewhere, for example from another data source or service. If you have, you need to make sure that you can republish the result as open data.

question.label: Does the source data have an open data certificate?
question.help: If the source data has an open data certificate, we know that it is open data and we can gather information from that certificate to help fill in the rest of the information that's needed here.

question.label: Where is its open data certificate?
question.help: The open data certificate demonstrates that the source dataset is available as open data.

question.label: What is the name of this data source?
Who publishes this data source?
question.help: Give the name of the publisher of this source of data.

question.label: What's their website?
question.help: Give the website of the other organisation who publishes this source of data.

question.label: How was this data used?
question.help: Describe how this source of data was used and which parts of the data you are making available come from this source. For example, name the columns that have been populated using this data.
question.requirement: You should supply information about which parts of the dataset are sourced from other datasets.

Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: The creator of a database automatically gets database rights where they spend substantial effort gathering, verifying and presenting data. They need to have specified a waiver or licence that covers the database rights in the data in order for you to republish it.

question.help: Indicate whether the licence says that you can reuse and republish this data under an open licence in the way that you are. Because the licence is not an open licence, you might need to seek legal advice to work out whether this is allowed.
question.requirement: You cannot publish open data that includes data that is sourced from a third party unless that third party has given you a licence to do so.

question.label: Was some of this data crowd-sourced?
question.help: Indicate whether this data includes information that was contributed by others. If it was, you need to ensure that they granted their permission to publish their contributions as open data.

question.label: Did contributions require judgement?
question.help: Indicate whether the contributors to your data needed to employ their creativity or judgement to make their contributions. For example, writing a description or choosing whether or not to include some data in a dataset would require judgement. If judgement is involved, the contributors will have copyright over their contributions.

question.label: Where is the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: A Contributor Licence Agreement either assigns the rights in the contributions to you, or licences them to you such that you can republish them.

question.label: Have all contributors agreed to the CLA?
question.requirement: The contributors to your data must all have agreed to a Contributor Licence Agreement to give you the right to republish their contributions as open data.

question.label: Does the data contain personal information?

option.label: the data doesn't contain anything about people at all
the data summarises information about people
the data is about individual people
option.help: Personal data is covered by data protection laws which means that when you collect it you have to tell people how it is going to be used. The same applies to data about organisations because some are run by just one person.

question.label: What usages did they consent to?
question.help: Describe what the people whose data is contained in this dataset were told about how the data will be used, when the data was collected.
question.requirement: To comply with data protection laws, data has to be used consistently with how individuals were told the data would be used. You should inform potential reusers about what that entails.

question.label: How has the data been anonymised?
question.help: Describe the processing by which the data has been anonymised to increase the difficulty of identifying individuals from the data.
question.requirement: Both personal data and aggregate data should be anonymised to ensure that the likelihood of discovering information about an individual is minimised.

question.label: Where is your privacy impact assessment published?
question.help: A Privacy Impact Assessment is a process for identifying privacy risks to individuals in the collection, use and disclosure of information.
question.requirement: When datasets contain personal data, a privacy impact assessment should be carried out to identify risks of releasing the data, mitigations against those risks, and to put in place processes that ensure that any breaches are handled effectively.

question.label: What kind of data release is this?

option.label: a one-off release of a single dataset
a one-off release of a set of related datasets
ongoing release of a series of related datasets
a service or API for accessing open data

question.label: Does the data underlying the API change over time?

option.label: no, the API simply provides easy access to unchanging data
yes, the API provides instant access to changing data

question.label: Will this data go out of date?

option.label: yes, this data will go out of date over time
option.help: For example, a dataaset that contains the current location of bus stops will go out of date over time.

option.label: yes, this data will go out of date over time but the data is timestamped
option.help: For example, demography statistics usually include a timestamp to indicate the time at which the statistics were relevant.
option.requirement: When releasing data that will go out of date over time, include timestamps that indicate when the data relates to within the data.

option.label: no, this data does not contain any time-sensitive information
option.help: For example, a dataset that contains the results of an experiment will not go out of date.
option.requirement: While a one-off release of time-sensitive data is appropriate for a pilot, you need a regular series releases for standard open data publication.

question.label: Does the data you capture change on at least a daily basis?
What type of dataset series is this?

option.label: regular copies of the complete database
option.help: Select this option if you are publishing copies of the contents of your database at regular intervals.

option.label: regular aggregates of changing data
option.help: Select this option if you are creating aggregate information at regular intervals, perhaps because the underlying data cannot be released as open data.

question.label: Is a feed of changes made available?
question.help: Indicate whether you make available a feed of the changes that occur to the data that you capture, such as new entries or amendments to existing entries.
question.requirement: As the data that you capture changes very frequently, you should provide a feed of the changes that occur so that it's easy for reusers to keep their copies up to date.

question.label: How frequently do you create a new release?

option.label: less frequently than once a month
at least every month
option.requirement: As the data you capture changes frequently, you should create a new dataset release every month.

option.label: at least every week
option.requirement: As the data you capture changes frequently, you should create a new dataset release every week.

option.label: at least every day
option.requirement: As the data you capture changes frequently, you should create a new dataset release every day.

question.label: What is the delay between creating a dataset and publishing it?

option.label: longer than the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you are creating a new version of the dataset every day, then choose this option if it takes more than a day for the dataset to then be published.

option.label: about the same as the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you are creating a new version of the dataset every day, then choose this option if it takes about a day for the dataset to then be published.
option.requirement: The delay between creating and publishing a dataset should be about the same as the gap between releases.

option.label: less than half the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you are creating a new version of the dataset every day, then choose this option if it takes less than twelve hours for the data to then be published.
option.requirement: The delay between creating and publishing a dataset should be less than half the gap between releases.

option.label: there is minimal or no delay
option.help: Choose this option if the delay is in the order of a few seconds if the datasets are created frequently, or a few minutes if they are made less frequently.
option.requirement: There should be minimal or no delay between creating and publishing datasets.

question.label: Do you also provide dumps of the dataset?
question.help: A dump is an extract of the data into a static file that developers can download to get hold of the whole dataset.
question.requirement: Dumps of the dataset should be made available to enable developers to download the entire dataset.

question.label: How frequently do you create a new dump?

option.label: less frequently than once a month
at least every month
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump every month.

option.label: at least every week
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump every week.

option.label: at least every day
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump every day.

question.label: Will this data be corrected if it contains errors?
question.help: Indicate whether the data will be corrected in cases where errors are discovered within the data.
question.requirement: Open data should be corrected if it is found to contain errors.

question.label: Where is your quality control process described?
question.requirement: Having a documented quality control process helps developers to understand how much to rely on the data that you make available.

question.label: Where is the latest report auditing your quality control process?

input.placeholder: Quality Control Process Audit Report URL

question.requirement: An audited quality control process gives developers reassurance that the quality control process that you have described is being adhered to.

question.label: What is the guaranteed availability of the service?

option.label: there are minimal guarantees about the availability of the service
at least 99% availability
option.requirement: You should guarantee at least 99% availability (less than 3.65 days downtime/year) of the service.

option.label: at least 99.9% availability
option.requirement: You should guarantee at least 99.9% availability (less than 8.76 hours downtime/year) of the service.

option.label: at least 99.999% availability
option.requirement: You should guarantee at least 99.999% availability (less than 5.26 minutes downtime/year) of the service.

question.label: For how long will the dataset be available in this way?

option.label: this dataset may disappear at any time
this dataset will be available in this form for at least one year
option.requirement: Provide a guarantee to developers who might want to reuse your data that it will be available in this form for at least a year.

option.label: this dataset will be available in this form for at least two years
option.requirement: Provide a guarantee to developers who might want to reuse your data that it will be available in this form for at least two years.

option.label: this dataset will be available in this form for at least three years
option.requirement: Provide a guarantee to developers who might want to reuse your data that it will be available in this form for at least three years.

question.label: What's the URL of the dataset?
question.help: Enter the URL of the dataset itself (for example a CSV file), not a page describing the dataset.

if.requirement: You must provide either a URL for the dataset or a URL for documentation about it.
You should have a URL that is a direct link to the data itself.

question.label: How do you publish the datasets in the series?

option.label: the data at a single "current" dataset URL is regularly updated
option.requirement: There should be a single URL that can always be used to download the current version of the dataset.

option.label: the URLs for each release follow a regular pattern
option.requirement: The URLs for different versions of the dataset should follow a regular structure.

option.label: you publish a list of the releases
option.requirement: There should be a document or feed that provides a list of all the available versions of the dataset.

if.requirement: You must provide access to releases of your data through a current URL, a discoverable series of URLs or through a documentation page.

question.label: What's the URL of the current dataset?
question.help: Enter the URL of the current version of the dataset itself (for example a CSV file). The content at this URL should change each time a new version is released. This should not be a page describing the dataset.

question.label: What's the URL template for the versions?
question.help: Use {variable} within the URL template to indicate changeable parts of the URL. For example http://example.com/data/monthly/mydata-{YY}{MM}.csv

question.label: What's the URL that gives a list of versions?
question.help: Enter the URL of a page or feed that provides a machine-readable list of the previous versions of the dataset.

question.label: What's the endpoint for the API?
question.help: Enter the endpoint of the API. If the API supports it, this should be a service description document.

if.requirement: You must provide either a URL for the API endpoint or a URL for the documentation about it.
You should have a service description document or similar single entry point for your API.

question.label: How do you publish the database dumps?

option.label: the data at a single "current" dump URL is regularly updated
option.requirement: There should be a single URL that can always be used to download the current dump of the database.

option.label: the URLs for each release follow a regular pattern
option.requirement: The URLs for different dumps database should follow a regular structure.

option.label: you publish a list of the releases
option.requirement: There should be a document or feed that provides a list of all the available dumps of the database.

question.label: What's the URL of the current dump?
question.help: Enter the URL of the current dump of the database itself (for example a CSV file). The content at this URL should change each time a new dump is created.

question.label: What's the URL template for the dumps?
question.help: Use {variable} within the URL template to indicate changeable parts of the URL. For example http://example.com/data/monthly/mydata-{YY}{MM}.csv

question.label: What's the URL that gives a list of available dumps?
question.help: Enter the URL of a page or feed that provides a machine-readable list of the available dumps of the database.

question.label: What's the URL that provides a feed of changes?
question.help: Enter the URL of the machine-readable feed that provides a list of the individual changes as they occur within the dataset, between dumps or versions of the dataset being created.

question.label: Is the data machine-readable?
question.help: A machine-readable format is one in which the information can be easily extracted from the data by a computer. For example, scanned photocopies of spreadsheets would not be machine-readable.
question.requirement: You should provide the data in a machine-readable format.

question.label: Is the data in an open standard format?
question.help: An open standard is one that is written through a defined fair, transparent and collaborative process and that anyone can implement. For example, XML, CSV and JSON are open standards.
question.requirement: You should provide the data in an open standard format.

question.label: What kind of data are you publishing?

option.label: human-readable documents
statistical data, such as counts, averages and percentages
geographic information, such as points and boundaries
other kinds of structured data

question.label: Do the formats used for documents include:

option.label: one that exposes the semantic structure of documents, such as HTML, Docbook or Markdown
option.requirement: You should publish documents in a format that exposes their semantic structure.

option.label: one that focuses on the format of documents, such as OOXML or PDF
option.requirement: You should publish documents in a format that is designed for documents.

option.label: only those not designed for documents, such as Excel, JSON or CSV

question.label: Do the formats used for statistical data include:

option.label: one that exposes the structure of the statistical hypercube data, such as SDMX or Data Cube
option.requirement: You should publish statistical data in a format that exposes its dimensions and measures.

option.label: one that treats the statistical data as a table, such as CSV
option.requirement: You should publish tabular data in a format that exposes the tables of data.

option.label: one that focuses on the format of tabular data, such as Excel
option.requirement: You should publish tabular data in a format that is designed for tabular data.

option.label: only those not designed for statistical or tabular data, such as Word or PDF

question.label: Do the formats used for geographic data include:

option.label: one designed for geographic data, such as KML or GeoJSON
option.requirement: You should publish geographic data in a format designed for geographic data.

option.label: a generic structured data format, such as JSON, XML or CSV
option.requirement: You should publish geographic data as structured data.

option.label: only those not designed for geographic data, such as Word or PDF

question.label: Do the formats used for structured data include:

option.label: one designed for structured data, such as JSON, XML, Turtle or CSV
option.requirement: You should publish structured data in a format designed for structured data.

option.label: only those not designed for structured data, such as Word or PDF

question.label: Are you using URIs to identify things in the data?
question.requirement: Use URIs to identify things in the data, so that they can be easily reference.

question.label: Do the URIs resolve to information about those things?
question.requirement: Identifiers that you use within your dataset should resolve to provide information about the things being identified.

question.label: Does the dataset include URIs outside your control?

option.label: yes
no, because it's not appropriate for this dataset
no, because the URIs you would point to don't exist
no, because the information at suitable URIs isn't reliable
no

question.help: We are asking this question to gather statistics about URI reuse and the reasons why people do not reference other peoples' URIs.

question.label: What's the contact email address about this dataset?
question.help: Provide an email address that people can contact with queries about the dataset.
question.requirement: You should have a contact email address so that people can get back in touch with you about any problems with the dataset.

question.label: Where do you recommend people discuss this dataset?
question.help: Provide a URL for the forum or mailing list where developers using this dataset should discuss it.
question.requirement: You should indicate where people using this dataset should discuss the data and how they are using it.

question.label: Where do you describe how to provide corrections?
question.help: Provide a link to a page that describes how people should provide corrections if they discover errors in the data.
question.requirement: You should provide instructions for people who discover errors in the data.

question.label: Where do you describe how to learn about corrections?
question.help: Provide a link to a page that describes how corrections will be communicated to reusers of the data.
question.requirement: You should provide an announcement mailing list or a feed to which reusers can subscribe to learn of corrections to the data.

question.label: Where do you list tools for working with the data?
question.help: Provide a link to a page that lists the tools that people and developers can use when working with the data.
question.requirement: You should provide a list of software libraries and other tools that help developers who want to work with the data. These can be created by you or by other members of the community.
